Are you trying to edit it with a gui?  Which one?  gedit?
You can try using "gksudo gedit /boot/grub/menu.lst".  If that doesn't work, try "sudo" instead of "gksudo"
sudo fdisk -l will show your partitions

You should also know that the numbering in grub can (in fact, usually is) different from the numbering used by the kernel.  For example, the kernel begins numbering at 1 (/dev/sda1, etc.) and grub begins numbering at 0 (hd0, etc.)
